vjdbv0.3_description: GenBank Accession ID = NCBI Accession, ENA, DDBJ (INSDC)
Assembly ID of the sequence (INSDC)
References the BioProject Accession (ID) (INSDC)
References the BioSample Accession (ID) (INSDC)
Date when the sample was collected
Country or sea area where the sample was collected
Title name of the sequnce based on GenBank entry
This sequence is a GenBank sequence
This sequence is a reference sequence
City where the sample was collected
Name of the country may contain the state name
Common name of the natural host, e.g. human
Length of the sequence
Molecule of the sequence, e.g. ssRNA
Wether the sequence is a partial or complete sequence
The level of the sequence completeness compare to the representative sequence in refseq in percentage
Gen Bank organism name, a taxonomic name at species level or below the species level.
Organization the submitter(s) is(are) affiliated with
Date when the sequence was released into a repository (GenBank, BV-BRC)
Name of the virus segment
NCBI Sequence Read Archive (SRA) accession ID
Submitter of the sequence
Tissue that was selected from the host
State/Region where the sample was collected
ENA analysis identifier
Assembly level (contig, scaffold, chromosome, complete genome)
Minimum length of consecutive Ns to be considered a gap
The assembly program
‘clone or isolate’
BV-BRC genome ID
Name of the institution to which the person collecting the specimen belongs
Health state of the host at the time of collection, e.g. diseased or healthy
The geographic location by latitude, where the sample was collected (DD)
The geographic location by longitude, where the sample was collected (DD)
Continent where the sample was collected
Describes the physical, environmental or local geographical source of the sample, e.g. soil
Name of the person that collected the sample
CORONA: The cuttoff used to determine if the sample is seropositive
References a ENA assembly to an ENA Experiment (could be redundant with Run)
Natural behaviour of the host
Main host disease diagnosis
Disease outcome in the host

The symptoms that have been reported in relation to the illness, such as cough, diarrhea, fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, runny_nose, shortness_of_breath, sore_throat. If multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon.
Taxonomic group of the host
Natural habitat of the avian or mammalian host
BVBRC Lab Host; common name of the lab host
NCBI Tax ID of the lab host
Species of the lab host. Scientific name of the host
Species of the natural host. Scientific name of the host
NCBI Tax ID of the natural host
Sex of the host
Unique ID by which singular subjects can be referred to
INFLUENZA: Method used to assess if a sample if flu positive/negative. When multiple once were used they are seperated by semicolon
INFLUENZA: Result of the given methods. Positive(P) or Negative(N). For multiple test the results are delimited by semicolon, e.g. P; P
INFLUENZA: Influenza virus classification
Boolean flag -- if record is in the BVRC then "yes"
INFLUENZA: The test result for other tested pathogens given as described by influenza test result
INFLUENZA: Was the sample tested for other pathogens? Insert the pathogenic organisms using semicolon as a delimiter, e.g. Newcastle. “None” is also valid
Lineage determined by Pangolin
Pangolin version used to determine the lineage
If the sample was only received and not collected provide the receipt date
RKI ID to link sequence and metadata
References a ENA assembly to an ENA Run
NCBI Tax ID of the sample species
Serological variety of a species characterised by its antigenic properties, e.g. H1N1
Common abbreviations of the species name
NCBI Tax ID of the species
Average sequencing depth across the sequence
Percentage of GC in the sequence
Percentage of Ns within the whole sequence
Generic name of the sequence (Name of the entry)
Number of contigs in the sequence
Sequence publication doi
Sequence publication pubmed ID
Last update date of the sequence in BVBRC (whole entry)
Version of the sequence (whole entry)
Institution that sequenced the sample
Insert size for paired reads
Instrument model used for sequencing
The protocol used to construct the library.
The design of the library including details of how it was constructed.
The library layout specifies whether to expect single or paired configuration of reads.
The name for the library if any.
The method used to select for or against, enrich, or screen the material being sequenced.
The library_source specifies the type of source material that is being sequenced.
The sequencing technique intended for this library.
Instrument platform used for sequencing, multiple are seperated (only for assemblys)
Why was the sample sequenced?
The name of the database where the sequence was originally released
Country of the submmiter institute
Country or location of the organization of the submitters.
VirJenDB sequence ID
VirJenDB metadata version
Unique ID given by the investigator as strain might not be unique
(Optional) Antiviral treatment used for this subject, such as zanamavir oseltamivir, amantadine. example: rimantadine
(Optional) Dosage of the treatment taken by the subject. example: 0.05 mg
(Optional) Duration of antiviral treatment after onset of clinical symptoms in days.example: 5
(Optional) Initiation of antiviral treatment after onset of clinical symptoms in days. example: 2.5
(Mandatory) The run data file model.
(Mandatory) The name or relative pathname of a run data file.
(Optional) Whether or not the subject is gravid. if so, report date due or date post-conception and specify which of these two dates is being reported.
(Optional) Was the subject confined to a hospital as a result of virus infection or problems occurring secondary to virus infection?
(Optional) Other descriptive information relating to the host.
(Optional) The number of days the illness lasted. example: 4
(Optional) Date the subject showed an onset of symptoms. format: yyyy-mm-dd. example: 2011-10-20

(Optional) The symptoms that have been reported in relation to the illness, such as cough, diarrhea, fever, headache, malaise, myalgia, nausea, runny_nose, shortness_of_breath, sore_throat. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon.
(Optional) Unique number of the strain which is reported as a part of the influenza strain name, such as a/chicken/fujian/411/2002(hxn1). format: integer number, example: 411
(Optional) Date that the influenza vaccination was administered to the subject over the past year. format: yyyy-mm-dd. example: 2007-05-12
(Optional) Influenza vaccinations that have been administered to the subject over the last year. example: 2009 h1n1 flumist

vjdbv0.3_name: Influenza-like Illness at the Time of Sample Collection
vjdbv0.3_description: (Optional) Is the subject at the time of sample collection considered to have influenza like illness?
(Optional) Dose used for the inoculoation experiment.
(Optional) Brief description of the protocol inoculation route.
(Optional) Is the virus stock used for the inoculation available?
(Optional) Does the h1n1 influenza virus originate from a swine-like outbreak (as opposed to a seasonal flu)?
(Optional) Description helping to explain what the cut off value means.
(Optional) Number of host individuals inoculated for the experiment.
(Optional) Use of personal protective equipment, such as gloves, gowns, during any type of exposure. example: mask
(Recommended) Reason for the sample collection.

(Optional) Conditions at which sample was stored, usually storage temperature, duration and location. in soil context: explain how and for how long the soil sample was stored before dna extraction (fresh/frozen/other).
(Optional) Free-form text describing the sample, its origin, and its method of isolation.
(Optional) Designation of information related to vaccination history as self reported or documented.
(Optional) Name of the strain from which the sample was obtained.
(Optional) Briefly describes the goals, purpose, and scope of the study.  this need not be listed if it can be inherited from a referenced publication.

(Optional) Exposure of the subject to infected human or animals, such as poultry, wild bird or swine. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state them separated by semicolon. example: poultry; wild bird

(Optional) Duration of the exposure of the subject to an infected human or animal. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state their duration in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. example: 1 day; 0.33 days (Units: year)
(Mandatory) Title of the study as would be used in a publication.
(Mandatory) Short text that can be used to call out experiment records in searches or in displays. this element is technically optional but should be used for all new records.
(Mandatory) Short text that can be used to call out sample records in search results or in displays.

(Optional) Setting within which the subject is exposed to animals, such as farm, slaughterhouse, food preparation. if multiple exposures are applicable, please state their type in the same order in which you reported the exposure in the field 'subject exposure'. example: backyard flock; confined animal feeding operation
(Optional) Dosage of the vaccine taken by the subject. example: 0.05 ml
(Optional) Lot number of the vaccine.
(Optional) Manufacturer of the vaccine.

vjdbv0.3_name: WHO/OIE/FAO Clade (Required for HPAI H5N1 Viruses)
vjdbv0.3_description: (Optional) Who/oie/fao clade should be included for highly pathogenic h5n1 viruses. example: 2.2
Old Virus name(s)
Byte range data of the sample in the sequence file without the header
The file location of the multiseq fasta file including the parent folder name
Date of the insertion into the VirJen database
Date of the update metadata in the VirJen database
A 'Realm' is the highest taxonomic rank into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subrealm' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Kingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subkingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Phylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subphylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Class' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subclass' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Order' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'suborder' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Family' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subfamily' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Genus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Subgenus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the ICTV.

A Species is the lowest taxonomic rank in the hierarchy approved by the ICTV. While subspecies levels of classification may exist for some viruses (e.g. Hepatitis C virus), the ICTV does not classify viruses below the species level. Defined by the ICTV.
A 'Realm' is the highest taxonomic rank into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subrealm' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Kingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subkingdom' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Phylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subphylum' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Class' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subclass' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Order' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'suborder' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Family' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subfamily' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Genus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.
A 'Subgenus' is a rank in the taxonomic hierarchy into which virus species can be classified. Defined by the NCBI.

A Species is the lowest taxonomic rank in the hierarchy approved by the NCBI. While subspecies levels of classification may exist for some viruses (e.g. Hepatitis C virus), the NCBI does not classify viruses below the species level. Defined by the NCBI.

The genotype or subtype of a viral sequence, as provided by the sequence submitter. This field comes from the "/serotype" field of the GenBank record and is showns as submitted. Consistency and accuracy may vary.
Individual isolate from which the sample was obtained
Host age given by a number. Is connected to Host Age Unit. The number should match the unit. E.g. 2 years
Unit that describes the host age. Is connected to Host Age. Should fit the number, e.g. 2 years
Host Ages in a uniform unit, tba
Host Age and Unit.
Indicator that sequences came from samples from a laboratory setting, and not from a wild host.
BVBRC NCBI TaxIDs of the lineage
Aggregation of the NCBI Taxonomy Names of the virus lineage.
Aggregation of the ICTV Taxonomy Names of the virus lineage.
This accession was used to define a species in the ICTV Taxonomy.
